instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3209: What is 820-3209? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPVCORE_S0_CPU: What is PPVCORE_S0_CPU? This is the primary power rail for the CPU that powers the CPU, known as CPU vcore. Without this, the machine will be braindead. .
definitions.PPVCORE_S0_AXG: What is PPVCORE_S0_AXG? This is vcore going to the CPUâ€™s integrated graphics processor for CPUs that have an integrated GPU. When this is missing on a device that has an integrated GPU and no discrete GPU, it usually means either no screen is detected, or the GPU integrated into the CPU is dead..
definitions.U6100: What is U6100? this is an SPI ROM chip that holds the BIOS which is necessary for the machine to POST or try and power on..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> boots but no chime/runs slow
threads.message:
[COLOR=#333333][FONT=Verdana][SIZE=13px]I have a macbook air that i booted up with a mac os on a usb(no ssd) and it booted fine but there was no chime and it runs slow. I replaced the keyboard due to a sticky spill but there doesn't look to be any liquid damage on the board.[/SIZE][/FONT][/COLOR]

Here is a video I took of the Activity Monitor screen of the computer when I booted into the os with my usb. The video is after about 15 minutes after booting. Should the cpu % be running that high for that long
[url]https://www.dropbox.com/s/zopvpb6kiughyc7/0000-4432.avi?dl=0[/url]

[COLOR=#333333][FONT=Verdana][SIZE=13px]I am not sure exactly where to go next after measuring the "Chipset "VCore" Rails". Here are the measurements I received.[/SIZE][/FONT][/COLOR]

[COLOR=#333333][FONT=Verdana][SIZE=13px]<SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> - 0.84v[/SIZE][/FONT][/COLOR]
[COLOR=#333333][FONT=Verdana][SIZE=13px]<SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0_AXG</SIGNAL> - showed 0.99v for about 4-5 secs after plugging in charger then 0v afterwards.[/SIZE][/FONT][/COLOR]
[COLOR=#333333][FONT=Verdana][SIZE=13px]<SIGNAL>PP1V5_S3_CPU_VCCDQ</SIGNAL> - 1.5v[/SIZE][/FONT][/COLOR]
[COLOR=#333333][FONT=Verdana][SIZE=13px]<SIGNAL>PP1V05_S0_CPU_VCCPQE</SIGNAL> - 1.05v[/SIZE][/FONT][/COLOR]
[COLOR=#333333][FONT=Verdana][SIZE=13px]<SIGNAL>PP1V8_S0_CPU_VCCPLL_R</SIGNAL> - 1.8v[/SIZE][/FONT][/COLOR]

[COLOR=#333333][FONT=Verdana][SIZE=13px]These measurements were made with the board/fan/ioboard isolated from the rest of the computer.[/SIZE][/FONT][/COLOR]

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> boots but no chime/runs slow
threads.message:
These are the voltages for <CHIP>U6100</CHIP> (SPI ROM)
[COLOR=#333333][FONT=Verdana][SIZE=13px]Pin 1 - 3.33v[/SIZE][/FONT][/COLOR]
[COLOR=#333333][FONT=Verdana][SIZE=13px]Pin 2 - 3.33v[/SIZE][/FONT][/COLOR]
[COLOR=#333333][FONT=Verdana][SIZE=13px]Pin 3 - 3.33v[/SIZE][/FONT][/COLOR]
[COLOR=#333333][FONT=Verdana][SIZE=13px]Pin 4 - 0v[/SIZE][/FONT][/COLOR]
[COLOR=#333333][FONT=Verdana][SIZE=13px]Pin 5 - 0v[/SIZE][/FONT][/COLOR]
[COLOR=#333333][FONT=Verdana][SIZE=13px]Pin 6 - 0v[/SIZE][/FONT][/COLOR]
[COLOR=#333333][FONT=Verdana][SIZE=13px]Pin 7 - 3.3v[/SIZE][/FONT][/COLOR]
[COLOR=#333333][FONT=Verdana][SIZE=13px]Pin 8 - 3.33v[/SIZE][/FONT][/COLOR]

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> boots but no chime/runs slow
threads.message: Did you try SMC reset? Battery is installed on machine ? Do you have ASD for test hardware can you write result?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> boots but no chime/runs slow
threads.message:
Thanks a lot man. 
I would always test it without the battery installed because I was lazy and didn't want to keep taking it out.
Now that I plug the battery in the cpu is running at less than 1% and works perfectly. I never knew that would cause the cpu to run higher?

Do you know why is that the battery would put less load on the cpu?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> boots but no chime/runs slow
threads.message: Im not sure why but after 2013 and later build machine SMC talking with battery if its not meet request or its cant talk create this problem.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> boots but no chime/runs slow
threads.message: run asd and see if there is a sensor issue. has the bios ever been flashed/chip changed/screwed with?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> boots but no chime/runs slow
threads.message: This is a 2012 so I had to do apple hardware test. The computer doesn't run slow anymore since I plugged the battery in but it still doesnt chime. Should I worry that it doesn't chime or is that an issue I should fix now.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> boots but no chime/runs slow
threads.message: Do a PRAM reset first. All audio circuitry is on the IO board, so could also be bad IO board or flat cable.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> boots but no chime/runs slow
threads.message: Thanks duke. I made another silly mistake. I only had the right speaker plugged in thinking that the chime would sound from either speaker. Issue solved.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> boots but no chime/runs slow
threads.message: Chime should come from either speaker on an Air as far as I know. Only on MB Pro it comes from sub woofer.
